newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: War veteran dies as Australia remembers Anzacs.
newsitem.headline: War veteran dies as Australia remembers Anzacs.

text.p: An old soldier collapsed and died and several others were taken to hospital on Friday during emotion-filled ceremonies across Australia marking Anzac Day.

Organisers said the annual day of remembrance -- considered by many to be Australia's true national day -- was the biggest in years as hundreds of thousands of war veterans and spectators participated in marches and dawn ceremonies.
In Sydney, where police estimated 120,000 people watched as war veterans paraded along downtown George Street, one man died after collapsing during the march.
Another veteran was in stable condition after a heart attack and at least five people were taken to hospital for observation after collapsing.
Anzac Day ceremonies commemorate the landing of Australian and New Zealand troops at Gallipoli, Turkey in 1915.
Only 11 Australasian Gallipoli veterans survive, 10 in Australia and one in New Zealand. One of the survivors, 103-year-old Roy Longmore, rode in a car in the march in Melbourne.

Australian and New Zealand troops stormed ashore at Gallipoli on April 25 as part of a British-led Allied force. About 7,000 Australians and 2,000 New Zealanders were killed during the eight-month battle against Turkish forces.
Though a massive defeat for the Allies, the battle widely is seen as the birthplace of Australia's national identity.
Former naval officer Jack "Crowbait" Crowhurst, 80, who served in the North Atlantic, Europe and North Africa in World War Two, said Anzac Day was a time of celebration.

"Those people that talk about this glorifying war - that couldn't be further from the truth," Crowhurst told The Australian Associated Press. "It's about sharing comradeship from days gone by - that's all we've got left now."
